Posts.Title: VISIBLE SIGNS OF LYMPHEDEMA - A PICTORIAL LindaLou53 glennie19

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2010 05:11PM sisterinspirit wrote: Suzy, Glad to hear that you have hooked up with a therapist.  It's good to have someone that you feel you can confide in and help you work through some of the issues that come with CA & LE.   Lord knows there are a lot of them.  Meds?  Sounds like that's not something you want to do.  Maybe an alternative to anti-D's is Same-e, which is a supplement.  I'm an anti-D girl myself, but I know people that swear by Same-e.    Years ago when my life was upside down because of an major injury, I met with a therapist who was looking for ways I could let go of some of my anger.  Sounds weird, but I came up with a wailing wall in my garage.  With help of friends, I collected colored glass.  Stood at the far end of the garage and threw it a hard as I could against the wall.  Watching that glass explode really helped to release the anger. Years later, I looked at the divits in the wall and thought how far I had come since that difficult time in my life. Guess what I am trying to say is do whatever you are comfortable with and what is right for you so that you can start to mend.   I cherish having you on this discussion board and am cheering you on in your struggle.  Deb

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2011 12:28PM sisterinspirit wrote: Hope, Congratulations on getting to the end of rads!  Yeah!  You are so not alone in what you are feeling.  I didn't have chemo, but remember the SE of rads and that feeling of being blitzed a couple of hours after treatment.  Eating a high protien diet helped and things really did get better after treatment was over.  Took awhile though.  Remember, the SE of rads is cummulative, so it may take a couple of weeks before you start to feel noticably better.   Would encourage you to talk with your dr if the anti d's aren't helping.  Sometimes it takes some time for them to kick in, or you many need to have the dose adjusted or try a different med.  Wish you could take a couple of more weeks off from work so you can take care of yourself.  You have been through a lot. Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2009 04:58PM sisterinspirit wrote: Hi TJW, Congratulations on finishing up rads!  You may find that things get a little worse over the next wek or so, but after that it should start to improve. I finished rads in Aug and am dealing with much of what you describe.  I've found anti inflammatories help with the irritation and inflammation caused by rads, and still take Aleve. Also take Neurontin for the nerve pain. I have very mild LE that first settled  into my elbow, which the therapist said is quite common.  Also have breast LE, but no back involvement.  Both my rad onc & med onc said that the nerve pain radiating up from my elbow that started during rads is from the SNB.  Maybe, but doesn't sound right to me.  Therapist thought nerve pain is a result of fluid pressing on nerves.  Have found that manual lymph drainage massage really helps. Happy to report that after 4 months, the nerve pain is starting to improve.  Until you can meet with the LE therapist, you might try elevating your arm above your heart and opening and closing your hand to let the fluid drain from your arm.  Also suggest keeping up with range of motion exercises which will help your shoulder. Check out http://www.stepup-speakout.org/ for suggestions on bras.  Binney, Otter, Kira and others have done a wonderful job in putting together this site.  I'm sure they will be along soon to offer their suggestions.  Gentle hugs to you

Posts.Title: Feeling a little Depressed...Mild Le. lexislove Suzybelle

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2009 05:18PM sisterinspirit wrote: Susan,  You are not alone!  I've had fibro since the mid 80's and went through radiation last summer.  I had a lot of zinging random pain in the breast during rads and afterwards that was quite uncomfortable.   The treatment center recommended anti-inflammatory meds, which did nothing to treat the pain.  When it started waking me up at night, I contacted my Dr who gave me a script for Darvocet, which helped alot.  I still have some pain in the breast and affected arm, probably related to lymphedema and continue to take an anti-imflammatory.  Staying on schedule with rads is very important, so I hope your Dr is able to adequately address your pain this week.  You might try gentle stretching exercises to maintain the range of motion in your shoulder.  Many people, myself included, also take anti-anxiety or anti-depression meds during treatment.  Don't hesitate to do whatever you need to to get through treatment, and be sure to get as much rest as possible.  My QOL has been greatly affected by fibro, and was impacted by the pain & discomfort of rads and the 4 hour round trip each day.   I'm happy to report though that the pain is subsiding and I'm able to get back to walking which helps me to manage my fibro.  I wish you the very best during this journey!
Posts.Title: radiation and fibromyalgia susiered Jknee54

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2009 01:44PM sisterinspirit wrote: Susan, So glad that you were able to get a script for pain meds.  Hope it helps!  I totally agree that QUALITY sleep is critical with fibro.  If you are not feeling refreshed after sleeping, you might give some thought to anti-depression meds, which can help you to get REM sleep.  I've been on a low dose for years and for me it's made all the difference in the world.  Sending healing thoughts your way!

Posts.Title: Singing the "When is your arm going to get better?" Blues Suzybelle o2bhealthy

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2009 07:54PM sisterinspirit wrote: Journey, I empathize with what you are going through.  I also had nerve pain in my arm after rads that eventually settled down to pins and needles.  Now 6 months later it's much better.  Find anti-imflammatory helps as well as neurontin. I saw a PT when the arm pain & swelling started and she gave me exercises and taught me MLD.  Got very limited relief and then swelling in breast & chest became a problem.  As I learned more about LE (thank you Binney, Otter, Kira & others) I realized that the first PT was not LANA certified and had actually only taken a weekend course.  Long story short, this last month I located a LANA certified therapist who is about 300 miles away and saw her three times.  She was just so much more knowledgeable about LE, and the MLD & exercise program is much more comprehsive.  The LE is mild enough that I do not need to wrap the arm.  Good news is that the aching in the arm is finally getting better.  She refitted me for the proper sized sleeve and glove and recommended that I wear them pretty much throughout the day.  I do MLD & exercise program once a day for a total of about 2 hours. If I think about it, I get pissed about the LE intruding on my life.  The good news is that with much better treatment I finally feel like I am getting control of this monster and hope that I will be able to return to cross country skiing next winter.  I would encourage anyone dealing with LE to seek out the best possible care by a LANA certified therapist.  It really does make a difference. I am in need of a compression bra or compression shirt that I can sew in the compression padding for breast & back.  Any suggestions? Hope you are able to find relief soon!

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2011 06:13PM sisterinspirit wrote: Cookiegal, Count me in as someone dealing with breast LE.  Lots of good suggestions here.  Would like to add a couple more.  I migrate between a sports bra and a slimmer by WearEase.  I can tolerate the sports bra sometimes, but at other times I think it is part of the problem.  I recently got the criss-cross shaper by Wear Ease and like it too.  Last week my truncal LE was really bothering me because of the heat and a couple of missed MLD sessions, so went in to be treated by my Chikley trained LMT and noticed a BIG difference.  Much more comfortable now, thank goodness! Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2011 03:05PM sisterinspirit wrote: Stavmom, It's your body, your arm and you are the one that will have to live with the consequences if the IV and blood pressure cuff aggravated the LE.  Regardless of whether IVs and blood pressure cuffs would make LE worse, your doctor should respect your concerns and find another solution.  Also, you may want to get a G sleeve to wear to alert medical personnel to avoid using your affected arm.  Check out g-sleeve.com.  Good luck to you!
Posts.Title: My arm surgeon stavmom stavmom

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2010 10:00AM sisterinspirit wrote: Becky, I think a blood pressure reading on my at risk arm triggered the LE, but I will never know for sure.  I am sorry you find yourself worried about getting lymphedema. There are many differing opinions about what percentage of women go on to get LE.  Several ranges I've heard is about 30%.  So many women with breast cancer do not develop LE.  That said, you are already taking the first steps to becoming informed which is excellent.  Check out the stepup-speakout.org website for superb information about risk reduction techniques and what to look for.  You might think about making an appointment with a well-qualified lymphedema therapist who can take baseline measurements and give you some personal tips.  There are many women who lead active productive lives that have LE.  Good luck to you. Deb
Posts.Title: Do you know what caused your Lymphedema? peanutchillibean sushanna1

Posts.Content: May 10, 2009 07:01PM sisterinspirit wrote: Kira, Thanks for responding.  Binney bumped up a post on this subject.   I've been following some of your other posts and think we probably have a lot in common. Good to hear that you are so active.  I'm getting back into the swing of things, slowly.  My LE is primarily in my upper arm, chest, breast & back.  I wear a sleeve during the day, and a glove when I garden or if my hand aches.  Need to come up with a better solution for breast compression  Have been wearing either sports bra or control cami.  MLD once a day and LE exercises when I think about it.  It's certainly better than it was, but sometimes it's hard to stay up beat, ya know?  Hope things go well for you as the weather warms up.   You are in my thoughts and prayers.  Member of the Club - I am so sorry that you have joined the club, but please know that you are not alone.  There is a ton of great info on this website as well as at stepout-speakup.org.  The ladies here have been through it and have a lot of great advice.  My best advice is that if you have not already done so, find a physical therapist who is LANA certified to help you with the LE.  The first person I went to took a weekend course in LE.  After thing weren't getting any better, I found someone who was certified and it made a big difference.  LE isn't pleasant, but things can definitely get better with proper treatment.  Good luck to you! Tucheta, Romania, wow!  What kind of treatment do they offer for LE where you are?

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2009 05:17PM sisterinspirit wrote: Shaw, Yes, sounds familiar.  I had my first post rad mammo only 3 months after end of treatment.  I wasn't ready physically or emotionally to do it.  Took 1/2 Ativan and darvocet beforehand and explained the situation to the tech.  She was wonderful in being as gentle as possible.  If it's any comfort, the last mammo 9 months after tx was much, much better.  For anyone reading this, if you are still experiencing pain after rads when it's time for your first mammo, consider taking medication and be sure to let the tech know how you are feeling.  It does get more comfortable over time!  Good luck!!

Posts.Title: Lymphedema discussions during BC awareness month kap24 Binney4

Posts.Content: May 18, 2010 10:10PM sisterinspirit wrote: Diane, It's always a difficult choice to decide what kind of treatment would be best for you. You are already taking positive steps to find out as much as you can before reaching a decision, so good for you. As someone who has been dealing with lymphedema as a result of a lumpectomy & SNB, I would strongly encourage anyone considering radiation to the axilla to seek a referral from their onc to a well-qualified lymphedema therapist prior to radiation so that baseline measurements can be taken and you can learn about risk reduction measures you can take to minimize the risk of lymphedema, and to learn what to look out for should you develop lymphedema.  Prevention, or in the alternative, early diagnosis and treatment of lymphedema can make a world of difference.  Check out the lymphedema thread on these boards and www.stepup-speakout.org website for for information on how to find a well-qualified therapist. As challenging as lymphedema is, it can be managed.  With cancer, I think it's important to fight the best fight possible, taking into account your personal situation and preferences. Best wishes to you as you go through the maze of treatment options.
Posts.Title: To radiate the axilla or not (neoadjuvant) HealthyDiane sisterinspirit

Posts.Content: May 22, 2010 06:48PM sisterinspirit wrote: So Kira, I went back & read your posts on the LE after SNB thread.  It's unfortunate that a well-meaning person like Lilly is denying even the possibility of LE after SNB, particularly in light of the one study that suggests that the rate of LE could be as high as 41%.  And for a person purported to be an expert giving opinions on LE when they are not educated on the subject is simply not acceptable.  I hope the moderators take note and remedy the situation.  No person should be harmed because of erroneous information provided on such an important site like BCO.  The reports you referenced reinforces the need for the medical community to come up with a standard definition of LE and for doctors treating breast cancer to take arm measureements before treatment begins and to provide literature to patients of what to look out for.  I don't think people understand just how prevalant LE is and the risk reduction techniques that should be practiced.  Again, many thanks to you and Binney and many others for helping us with this steep learning curve!

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2010 04:26PM sisterinspirit wrote: Mindy, I know the despair that you feel at the beginning of the journey.  To get the diagnosis of cancer and then hall all of the questions that follow without any clear answers.  And I know what's it like to feel that you don't have a strong support team.  But don't give up!  Just take a deep breath and do what you need to do to get through this day, this hour, this minute.  The path will become more clear as you start the journey.  You are at the very toughest part right now. If you haven't checked it out yet, there is a thread over on Fundraising Opportunities called "broke and heading to a tent in the woods".  Looks like there is some good information from others who have dealt with having limited resources. You deserve to get good medical care and to get treatment that is right for you and right for your situation. I hope you can find your way through the financial quagmire so you can get on the road to recovery. Hang in there and let us know how you are doing. Deb

Posts.Title: PLEASE TAKE A MINUTE TO HELP! Binney4 C130sunshine

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2010 12:46PM sisterinspirit wrote: Oh Suzy, Dawn and Lowrider are so right.  You've been through so much this year, it is very normal to grieve over the losses you have experienced.  Loss of being invincible, loss of self-image, loss over the life you knew.  I'm a bit further down the road and I can tell you it does get better as you adjust to the new you, At times pain is a big issue for me too.  I about lost it during my last flare just before Labor Day.  Riding my bike for two miles started it all off.  Anyway about pain control.  You wil be so much better off if you are able to get control over your pain before it gets too bad.  I recommend you talk with your onc or PCP and let them know that you are struggling with pain.  I have found that pain meds I used to take like Aleve and ibuprofen now make my LE worse.  Binney and Kira can explain why.  I was taking tylenol, but honestly, it didn't do much for me and made my liver unhappy.  Because of my fibromyalgia, I have taken low-dose tricyclic and SSRI anti depressants for years.  They help with my sleep and they are great pain moderators without being addictive or narcotic. They work very well.  At times when my LE flares, I take Darvocet which is a narcotic.  I don't like the thought of taking a narcotic, but there are times when it is the appropriate thing to do,  It really helps get me through the tough times without having a complete meltdown. Additions to Binney's flare care techniques: Distraction.  Read a good book or magazine or listen to music, anything to distract you from how you are feeling.  Meditation or prayer.  There are some great guided meditation tapes out there.  Comfort.  Whatever is most comforting to you.  I wrap myself up in the quilts my sisters made.  Know it won't last forever, and remind yourself of that frequently.  And the best, chocolate! I do hope you will contact your dr about your pain, as it will also make it easier to deal with everything else you have on your plate.  Hope you are feeling better soon and are back to being your usual spunky self! Gentle hugs, Deb
Posts.Title: pain management/mental health Suzybelle kcshreve
